page.lettertext:
fol.164r
Bo
dly
S
r
. Upon the first daie of this moneth at one instant I receaved three
letters from you, 2 of the xxj of the last month, and the 3
d
of the 29
by both the former it appeareth, that upon the receipt of my l
re
s of
e 7 of
July, declaring her
Ma
ties
purpose to rescue
Brest,
and request to have
their assistance by sea, you had conference with the
States
about the
same, in whome you found good disposition to assist her Ma
tie
in that
enterprise with 9 or 10 shippes. But yet because you were not able to
delcare unto them the particularities of hir Ma
ties
resolution for the time
and the Rendez voz, neither
w
th
the number of hir Ma
ties
shippes, soldiers,
Munition and powder they could not make present determination with
you, and yet nevertheles it appeareth by your second Letter,
at
Mons
r
Car
o
had advertised the States particularlie of her Ma
ties
purpose, as the same
was determined in my house the 15 of
e laste past and conferring with
you theruppon, you alleadged that you had not understood the particular
pointes thereof, and soe it seemeth by your writing, that for lacke of your
information, the matter was at a staye, although it might appeare well
unto you by their owne reporte, that her Ma
ties
demaundes was to have 9 or
10 shippes for tenne monneths, wherein they found no difficultie to yeald unto
e Quene, nor to
e provisi
o
of 20000 waight of powder: and yet they could
not well conceave what was ment by a request of 2 moneths victuels for
2000 men: they also seemed lacke in
at there was noe mention made of mu-
nicion, nor of greater quantitie of powder, for
e recoverie of
e Forte of
Brest. And by your letter of
e 28 yt seemeth that upon a l
re
written by
Mons
r
de Caron unto them the very xv
th
daye of July, that he was coun-
termanded the same daye, by all which uncerteinties it hath fallen out very
unlukelie; that these preparations of
e States have honge in suspence: and
ca
n
ot be executed soe soone as
e tyme requireth. But for clearing of all these
former scrupules, you shall understand
at
e very xv
th
of July. Mons
r
Caron was directed not onelie what to demaunde of the States, but at what
tyme the same was required, and what were the forces than determined
by her Ma
tie
. And though it was true that the same daye he was
written unto by my sonne upon the Quenes co
m
andement,
at he should
staye the sending awaye of his l
re
s for
e present, untill he might be newly
spoken withall, which was ment to be
e next daye, and having received
at countermande he made aunswer presentlie, that he had alreadie sent
awaye his l
re
s to
e states, agreable to
e motions made to him the sayd
xv
th
wherwith her Ma
tie
beyng made acquainted, she was very well
sufficed, and allowed of his dilligence, and soe untill the very tyme of
e
receite of this your latter letters, we were in opinion and expectation
fol.164v
to have heard of these assistances of
e States Shippes and other th
eir
provisions to have bin at
Portesmouth,
before
e fift of this present
mo-
neth. And now to explaine
e demaundes as they were made, It i
s true
there were demaunded 12 shippes at
e least, and victuels for 2000 me
n
t
might serve by lande for two months, and as I thincke but 20000 w
eight
of powder, without anie wordes of Muniti
o
. But now to reduce our
de-
mandes to more certeintie, her Ma
tie
can be contented w
th
te
n
e shippes
, if
otherwise
e States shall not yeld to 12 and for
e victuels, considering
that
which is alleadged of
e darthe of victuals there and the cheapenes heer
e that
demaunde maye be forborne, although at this present by
e unseaso
n
abl
enes of
e yeare I thincke the darth of victuels is more heere then there, cons
ide-
ring the provision of Corne that readilie is to be had out of the East Co
ntries
into those. As for the small quantitie of powder demanded, I think
the
same was mistaken in writing for indeede 20000 waight of powder is
little
more then 8 lasts, soe as it is now rather required to have three
score
thowsand, which is not xxx lasts and yet if xxx lasts maye be had, it
shall well content her Ma
tie
, and soe I hope they will yeald there
unto
and if it shalbe more, it shalbe more thanckefull. At this tyme
we
have had speeche with Mons
r
Caron, declaring to him
e uncertain
ties
gathered by your letter; whereunto for our better satisfaction, he shew
eth us
l
res
written unto hym from
e Haghe
e 29 of July, wherby in exp
ress
wordes they write,
at they are readie to send awaye their assistance
, ma-
king noe mention of any doubt or delaye therein, and yet neverthele
s he
is directed to write backe againe thither with all speede, to haste
n the
same, by whome I doe send these my l
re
s to you at this tyme.
From
e Court this 3
d
of August
1594
.
We are certeinlie advertised
at
Laon
is rendred to
e
Kinge
and
e D. de Mayne and
Aum ale
and chassed out of
Amiens
.
